October 13, 1991: Fiction
SCARLETT, by Alexandra Ripley. (Warner, $24.95.) The sequel to Margaret
Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind."
THE SUM OF ALL FEARS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $24.95.) Middle Eastern
terrorists edge the world to the brink of nuclear war.
THE DOOMSDAY CONSPIRACY, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $22.) An
American naval officer, assigned to investigate a balloon accident in the Alps, has
to contend with a mysterious force.
NIGHT OVER WATER, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $23.) High drama on the Pan
American Clipper's last trans-Atlantic flight after the outbreak of World War II.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
SAINT MAYBE, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $22.) The struggles of a young man to
atone for the wrong he feels he has done his older brother.
THE DECEIVER, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $22.50.) To escape forced early
retirement, Sam McCready recalls his years in the British secret service.
THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that his
firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities.
FLOWERS IN THE RAIN, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $20.) A
collection of short stories, many of them set in Scotland.
THE DUCHESS, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $21.) An American woman, in
Scotland to marry a duke, finds a mysterious stranger more attractive.
RUSSKA, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $25.) Eighteen centuries in the lives of
four families of different cultures residing in a Russian village.
THE KITCHEN GOD'S WIFE, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $22.95.) A Chinese-
American matriarch tells the harrowing story of her life.
THE DRAGON REBORN, by Robert Jordan. (Tor, $22.95.) The fate of a man
doomed to save and then destroy the world; part of the "Wheel of Time" fantasy
series.
GONE WITH THE WIND, by Margaret Mitchell. (Macmillan, $21.95.) The 1936
novel about Scarlett O'Hara, Rhett Butler and the Georgia plantation Tara.
OUTER BANKS, by Anne Rivers Siddons. (HarperCollins, $19.95.) An interior
decorator comes to terms with herself at a college reunion.
October 13, 1991
Non-Fiction
ME: Stories of My Life, by Katharine Hepburn. (Knopf, $25.) The actress's
memoirs.
UH-OH, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $19.) Reflections on life's commonplaces,
from meat loaf to pet dogs to fireflies.
LA TOYA, by La Toya Jackson with Patricia Romanowski. (Dutton, $19.95.)
Growing up in a leading show business family, as experienced by Michael
Jackson's sister.
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures through the
centuries.
FIRE IN THE BELLY, by Sam Keen. (Bantam, $19.95.) A philosopher explores the
changing role of the male in today's society.
PARLIAMENT OF WHORES, by P. J. O'Rourke. (Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly,
$19.95.) A humorist's attempt to explain the workings of the Federal Government.
J. EDGAR HOOVER, by Curt Gentry. (Norton, $29.95.) The career of the longtime
Director of the F.B.I.
HARD COURTS, by John Feinstein. (Villard, $22.50.) A journalist's behind-the-
scenes look at a year of professional tennis.
TOUJOURS PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $20.) The charms of rustic
Provence, as savored by a London advertising man who moved there.
EXPOSING MYSELF, by Geraldo Rivera with Daniel Paisner. (Bantam, $21.50.)
The autobiography of the television personality.
CHUTZPAH, by Alan M. Dershowitz. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A prominent law
professor's reflections on the lot of Jews in America, past, present and future.
ANNE SEXTON, by Diane Wood Middlebrook. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.)
The life of a gifted poet who was hampered by mental illness.
WHEN YOU LOOK LIKE YOUR PASSPORT PHOTO, IT'S TIME TO GO HOME,
by Erma Bombeck. (HarperCollins, $19.95.) The tribulations of travel suffered in all
parts of the world.
THREE BLIND MICE, by Ken Auletta. (Random House, $25.) How ABC, CBS and
NBC lost their dominance of the television world during the 1980's.
DAVE BARRY TALKS BACK, by Dave Barry. (Crown, $18.) A collection of
columns by the syndicated humorist.
